titleStmt.title: Venus and Adonis; or, the Triumphs of Love.

notesStmt.note: Venus and Adonis; or, The Triumphs of Love (1713) is a mock opera that brings together Punch and gods from classical mythology. It is the only printed play by Irish puppeteer Martin Powell, who met with brief but dazzling success in England at the beginning of the 18th century. He mostly played in Convent Garden in London, but he also staged plays in Bath, Oxford and Bristol. Although Powell sometimes performed plays inspired by English legends or ballads sold by book peddlers, he also wrote original texts – one of which being Venus and Adonis. Powell’s preface suggests that he worked with Italian machinists. It would also seem that two characters (Jupiter and Proserpina) were played by trained monkeys.

projectDesc.p: Text collected during the PuppetPlays project funded by European Union (Grant Agreement 835193) under Horizon 2020. The PuppetPlays project aims to re-evaluate the contribution of the puppets repertoire to the construction of European cultural identity. Its main goals is to collect a corpus of representative plays from Western Europe (Germany, Austria, Belgium, Spain, France, Great Britain, Italy, Netherlands, Portugal, Switzerland) between the 17th and the 21th century. It also tries to identify the characteristics of puppet dramaturgy and their variations depending on eras, cultural spheres, producing conditions, and the aimed public.
This edition is the result of university research work, reviewed by the principal investigator.

div.head: To the most ingenious Machionists of the Hay-market Theatre
div.p: language, other for farce; but all agree in this, that plays are but diversions in what kind soever understood. Now left I should appear ignorant of the fashion, and thought uncapable of following it, I am obliged to say something too; but since I am resolved against any long-learned discourse, I shall only give you a taste of my experience, which I hope may be pleasant and diverting.
You have done me the honour in giving me a sight of your incomparable fancy in machinery, I have ever since made it my chiefest thoughts to find out some way whereby

I might manifest my desire of expressing my obligation, which I cannot do in a more publi[c] manner than thus. The end of this address is, that I am in great hopes this little opera will gain a greater reputation, it being patronized by you, whose genius is so great and brains so fertile, that certainly the opera of France and Italy must drop whilst you absent yourselves from thence to instruct the stage of Great-Britain. Such projectors as you give new life to invention; your foreign pencil likewise instructs painters. Indeed, the latter two are akin, being the effects of fancy, and one
oftentimes helps out the other, as may be seen in your last great and rich machine.

All must own, that it was most ingenious, surprising, and uncommon, particularly the vast number of curling clouds, like a mighty sea, it brought before it; and as it gently moved towards the spectators, it appeared more wonderful to see those raref[ied] clouds striving to outvie each other in brightness; their quick contraction, and sudd[en] forming themselves to a temple. For my part, I was astonished at the sight, and fanc[ied] myself to be in some c[e]lestial sphere. Oh! that

my little inventions were not confined like a butterfly in a tar-barrel, and had a stage in circumference containing an acre, yet not one of my wooden-headed managers would be capable of bringing so great a machine to such perfection, which I dare not so much as imitate. My callow-winged fancy dare not soar so high, lest it should be compared with the foolish arcades, that presumed, that if they could once attain to the top of a certain mountain they might reach the moon; but when they, with a great deal of pains, had reached the top of it, how much they fell short of their aim is easy

to guess. So least my aspiring thoughts should make me share the same fate, I’ll end this epistle, strengthened with the hopes, that when you have seen this little performance, you’ll do me the honour of recommending it to your friends abroad, and you will highly oblige,
Your most obedient Humble servant, M. Powell.

div.head: The Preface to the Reader
div.p: That which induced me to print this little opera was in my great patron, Punch, who, meeting with some reflections from the greater opera, comparing his little fabric to a tar-barre[l], and his person to a butterfly, which highly displeased him, and to vent his spleen beat his empty noddle against every scene.

And all the little gentry seemed to resent the same, and discovered their chagr[in] by nodding their wooden heads at each other; nor could their fury be appeased, till King Bladud, and Whittington, promised to supply them with a large sum of money, to enable them to erect an opera, which could not be contained in a tar-barrel, and so the rupture ceased.

lg.l: As the industrious bee, in verdant meads,
Oft draws mellifluous juice from rankest weeds;
So I, from urns of lovers long since slain,
Produce most noble acts, and spare no pain,
Nor cost, if I to please you may attain.
Venus and Adonis, of beauty bright,
I humbly offer to your piercing sight.
No loose expression here shall pass for wit,
No blasphemy affright, the trembling pit:
No modish curse, shall lard a trifling scene,
Nor roaring hero, swear and nothing mean.
To choose diversions, such shall be my care,
As shall not give offence to any virtuous ear;
Such as shall give to everyone delight,
Such as you’ll see presented here tonight,
Will give offence to neither church nor state,
Burlesque no text, buffoon no magistrate;
Laugh at no law, but with such caution move,
As will, if possible, deserve your love.
No longer shall poor Punch in fetters toil,
Nor with complaints his tedious hours beguile,
Whilst you thus shine upon him with a smile;
He still for blessing on you all shall pray,
And tributary thanks shall thus forever pay.

castItem.roleDesc: A little smooth-faced youth finely dressed, adorned with the best spangles and gold-tabby that came last from Italy, and never seen on the stage before.
A trifle; a very great mischief-maker; one who makes old men children, and boys set up for men; newly arrived from the hands of the workman.
That by his mock rattling breaks all things to pieces. Performed by a mischievous ape.
Your old friend Punch, who from a coxcombly shepherd is transformed by Jupiter to the mock god of battle, and bantered with the love or Proserpine.
A devilish goddess that has ruined millions of people, and never was so sorry till her loved Adonis was killed, dressed like the fair deceivers that imitate her.
The reverse of Minerva, looks like an alderman with a grave face, and little wisdom, who sings much, and consequently requires little wit.
Whom Punch runs mad for; performed by a monkey lately dead, who sings as well as if she had been living.

div.head: Venus and Adonis: or, the triumphs of Love.
Act I

lg.l: Welcome, love’s goddess, and royal mother:
What brought bright Venus here to Cupid’s bower?
How came that lovely face with grief oppress[sed]?
Can Cupid give his beauteous mother rest?
Cupid, my son, whose uncontr[ol]ling sway
Makes all c[e]lestial deities obey.
O force Adonis’ heart to yield to love,
Of all thy works, the master-piece ’twill prove.
O, kindle flames in him, like those in me,
And grant, that I his beauty soon may see.
Let me then view those eyes, whose shining light,
Alone can pleasure give to Venus’ sight.
Just like a ship, whilst every mountain-wave
Threatens the ma[r]iners with a gaping grave;
Such is my case, and so my state appears,
Alike distracted, between hopes and fears.
Into the woods I’ll go, and there complain,
Nor think of pleasure, till you come again.
Despair not, mother, Adonis shall be thine,
Or never let Cupid in your favour shine.
From yonder mount, that overlooks. My bower,
Adonis now descends; ‘tis Venus happy hour.
With my keen dart, I will so pierce his breast,
That none but your soft arms, shall give him rest.

div.head: Scene 2
A forest
div.stage: Enter Punch in a shepherd’s habit.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: Was ever mortal so affronted? To be scorned by all the nymphs, and denied to hunt with the swains? God Pan too, with his cloven-footed gang of satyrs to mock me. [G]ad’s bobs, now I’m in the humour to abuse [th]em all. Jupiter is a juggler, Mars is a bully, Apollo a poor paultry poet, Bacchus a drunken drawer, Mercury a morris-dancing pimp, Venus a town-jilt, Cupid a blind archer, and Pan a savage cuckold.

lg.l: And I’m resolved, if I meet [th]em in the chase,
I’ll throw my doubled fist in their face.
And scorns the power,
That all the gods adore?
He that dare slight the beloved muses’ sound,
With my keen arrow, shall receive his wound.
I’ll curse thee with loving Proserpine.
With my swift wings I’ll take my speedy flight,
Lest young Adonis should escape my sight.

sp.speaker: Punch
sp.p: I will justify, that a man had better have the Devil ride through his guts with a bundle of thorns at his bre[e]ch, than to be in love; and as the Devil would have it, with Proserpine. Sure I was in a woundy heat when I went to hell to choose a mistress: it was the other day that I was railing against love and poetry; and now I think of nothing else, and eat nothing but poetry, and now it wombles to come forth. See, she comes.

lg.l: Proserpine, thou whose beauty doth enrich us,
Tell me the cause, why thou dost so bewitch us:
This day my love was born, though not begotten,
This day I’ll think on, when I’m dead and rotten.
And though thy coyness, and thy pretty scorn,
Makes many wish, that thou ha[d] never been born;
Yet for my part, this I will swear and say,
I wish thy time of birth were every day.
So Venus looked, when the Idalian boy
Confirmed her beauty, with the curse of Troy;
Just so she looked, with such an air she smiled,
When she two rival goddesses beguiled.
Thy double tire of teeth do show, forsooth,
Whiter than ivory, or a bitch’s tooth,
Thy voice like bird in hedge, in time of Spring,
Do[e]s bewitch me confoundedly to sing.
Proserpine, ’tis to thee I sing,
I love thee more than anything.
Love and fire’s got in my head,
Then take me quickly to thy bed,
But what to do need not be said.
With a ho, with a ha,
With a ho, ho, ho, etc.
Love and fire’s got, etc.
She’s gone! She’s sunk! She’s dead! She’s buried!
I shall go mad, I’ll roar, and rant, and swear;
And all this I will do, because I dare.
Since she’s dead, what method shall I take
To raise some monument that’s wondrous great?
To enrich her tomb, nor shrines, mor altars spare,
But strip the shining gods to make it rare.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: The palace of Venus, adorned with proper ornaments, and the statues of the Pantheon heightened with gold.

lg.l: Let music sound from the c[e]lestial sphere,
Whilst satyrs, swains, and nymphs, divert us here.
Let mortal join the deities above,
To crown the triumphs of my glorious love.
Hark! Diana’s horn invites me to the chase:
The gods in full divan have all decreed,
That a most monstrous boar this day shall bleed.
Adonis, wil[l] thou then from me be gone,
And leave me he[re] to mourn and sigh alone?
Regar[d] thou not the flower of my youth,
When of my love, thou ha[s] so large a proof?
Thou captivated ha[s] long since my hear,
And wil[l] thou now unkindly from me part?
O, do not go, the danger’s very great;
Thy death, I much do fear, it will create.
Let my fair goddess, from sad grief forbear,
For no danger in these huntings are;
Let Venus then, banish al thoughts of fear.
He that from beauty’s charms too long doth rove,
Never yet knew the sweets of youthful love.

div.head: Scene 2
div.stage: The Horn sounds, the wild boar crosses the stage; and after him God Pan, Adonis, Swains, and Satyrs in chase. Re-enter Adonis, wounded.

lg.l: Ah, what a sad unfortunate Man was I,
Not to observe the tears of her fair eye:
Her sweet persuasions were, I should not go;
Still to her suit I ever answered, no.
And yet grim Death, it is not thee I fear,
For her alone is all my grief and care.
Adieu, fair Venus, adieu to thee a while,
Our future joys will make us both to smile.
What cruel fate brought this sight hither?
Why did we not die both together?
How sad and unhappy is Venus’ fate,
Thus to be made at once unfortunate?
He’s gone! He’s gone! The glorious youth is fled:
Then why do I in vain bewail the dead?
My doves and chariot, now with speed prepare,
His Soul I’ll overtake, though flying through the air;
The deities above, I then will move,
For life eternal to my god-like love.

div.head: Act IV
div.stage: Soft musi[c] as the machines descend. After the first machine, Venus and Pallas descend in two several machines; at the feet of Venus two dogs, and at Pallas’ an owl and a cock. The two lesser machines break through the larger, and move to the front of the stage.

lg.l: Let great Apollo now the muses join,
Whi[le] I, in tears, do mourn the youth divine:
For all my earthly joys at once are fled,
My beloved Adonis being dead.
If now the smiles of Pallas ought you prize,
My dearest Venus, dry up thy watery eyes:
The gods all mourn throughout their spheres
To see love’s Goddess drowned in tears.
Drowned in tears,
Drowned in tears,
To see love’s Goddess drowned in tears.

div.stage: Jupiter and Proserpine descend in the front of the stage, and sing; whilst Mars descends in his palace, and moves towards them.

lg.l: O Proserpine, look up and see
Great Jove descend to visit thee;
Likewise Punch, by thee so hated,
To great Mars is now translated:
Then take the God into thy arms,
Lest thundering Jove, should crush thy charms,
Crush thy charms,
Crush thy charms,
Lest thundering Jove, should crush thy charms,
Crush thy charms,
Crush thy charms,
Lest thundering Jove, should crush thy charms.
The commands of love I’ll obey,
Love is dangerous to delay,
Since Punch has stolen my heart away.
Let Pluto rave, and tear his brain,
’Tis Mars, or Punch, must quench my flame,
Quench my flame,
Quench my flame,
’Tis Mars, or Punch, must quench my flame.
Then take great Mars into thy arms
And thou shalt rifle all my charms:
In wanton love whole nights we’ll range,
And now and then a haugh we’ll change.
Let’s now ascend with Jove above,
And with our haugh proclaim our love,
With a ha, ha, ha, ha, proclaim our love.

div.head: Iris descends on a rainbow, and speaks the epilogue

lg.l: Swift! Swifter still! For methinks I move to[o] slow.
What holds my silver wings from making haste,
When every cloud I see sails by so fast?
Luna flies wrapped in foggy clouds of night,
To shun the rays of bright Apollo’s light.
See with what haste the feathered hours run,
To dress the gaudy chariot of the sun:
Whilst nymphs and swains, at love’s bright alter meet,
Their sacred vows to pay at Venus’ feet.
For till old time his c[ry]st[a]l glass hath hurled,
And from it lost the ashes of the world,
No mortal shall be free from Cupid’s dart,
But love shall triumph over every heart.

div.stage: As Iris ascends, the clouds break, and discover the British machin[e]ry, beautified with the figure of her Britanni[c] majesty, seated on her throne, attended by the honourable House of Peers, and Chief Ministers of State.
The Machines break into several triumphant arches, and form themselves into double and treble prospects, with all the trophies taken from the enemy under their feet.
